item.title: In Battle for Hong Kong, the Field Has Tilted Toward Beijing
item.description: Unlike China’s retreat after big protests in 2003, this time it is not likely to back down.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators at a rally outside the Legislative Council building in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

item.title: Extradition Protesters in Hong Kong Face Tear Gas and Rubber Bullets
item.description: The demonstrators were mostly peaceful, but some hurled bricks and bottles as they charged officers guarding the Legislative Council.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: As Protesters Fill Hong Kong’s Streets, Businesses Are Alarmed, Too
item.description: A wave of concern has spread through a community of foreign consultants, investors and executives who have made the territory their home and regional headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters occupied roads near Hong Kong’s Legislative Council building on Wednesday.

item.title: Shinzo Abe’s Latest Diplomatic Long Shot: Peacemaking in Iran
item.description: Japan’s prime minister arrives Wednesday in Tehran, placing himself directly in the middle of a tense confrontation between the United States and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan during a welcome ceremony in Tehran, on Wednesday.

item.title: Hong Kong Protesters and Police Battle With Bricks, Bottles and Tear Gas
item.description: Some demonstrators, protesting an extradition bill, threw bricks, bottles and umbrellas at riot police officers guarding the city’s Legislative Council. The police responded with tear gas, pepper spray and rubber bullets.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters were engulfed in tear gas.

item.title: Boris Johnson Emerges to Face Reporters’ Questions. Six of Them.
item.description: Criticized as hiding from scrutiny, the front-runner to be Conservative Party leader spoke at a campaign event, vaguely, about his Brexit plans and college cocaine use.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Boris Johnson started his Conservative Party leadership campaign in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Houthis Strike Saudi Airport, Escalating Yemen Conflict
item.description: The Houthi missile wounded 26 people. Fighting between the Houthi rebels and the Saudi-led coalition has escalated in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee

item.title: Russian Police Arrest Hundreds at Protest, Including Navalny, After Reporter’s Release
item.description: Riot police dragged demonstrators from the crowd and arrested news photographers and reporters at a protest called to support the journalist Ivan Golunov, who had been detained and abruptly freed.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Organizers called the march in Central Moscow on Wednesday to protest against what they called the impunity of law enforcement agencies.

item.title: Philippines Accuses Chinese Vessel of Sinking Fishing Boat in Disputed Waters
item.description: The collision put the lives of 22 crew members at risk, officials said, as the two countries stake competing claims to the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: Protesters marched in Manila on Wednesday to denounce Chinese actions in the South China Sea.

item.title: Sara Netanyahu Cuts Plea Deal in Catering Case
item.description: The wife of Israel’s prime minister was accused of misusing about $100,000 in public funds. The prime minister’s own corruption case still looms over his run for another term.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Sara Netanyahu, the wife of the Israeli prime minister, at a Jerusalem court in 2018.

item.title: What We Know About the Dominican Republic Tourist Deaths
item.description: Six Americans have died at resorts on the popular Caribbean island, and their families are raising questions about the circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:description: The Punta Cana region of the Dominican Republic, on the nation’s eastern shore, is known for its beaches.

item.title: Two More Ebola Cases Diagnosed in Uganda as First Victim, 5, Dies
item.description: Fears grew that the year-old outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo could spread more in what one expert called a “truly frightening phase.”
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: A border crossing in Congo on Wednesday just across from a Ugandan town, Bwera, Ebola patients were being treated at a hospital.

item.title: A 13-0 World Cup Rout? Thailand Is as Proud as Ever
item.description: The women’s loss to the United States produced the most lopsided score in World Cup history. But soccer fans in Thailand say they were just happy their team was there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:description: Alex Morgan of the United States, center, scored a record-tying five goals against Thailand at the Women’s World Cup in Reims, France, on Tuesday. The United States won, 13-0.

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Sister Meets With South Korean Officials at Border
item.description: Mr. Kim’s sister, Kim Yo-jong, delivered a letter from him expressing condolences on the death of a former South Korean first lady, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: Trump, Britain, Catalan Leaders: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Hong Kong Protests Live Updates: Legislature Postpones Extradition Debate Again
item.description: Following clashes between protesters and riot police, lawmakers said they would not meet on Thursday to discuss the bill that would allow extradition to mainland China.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers near the Legislative Council building in Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Russian Military Reports Cease-Fire in Syria
item.description: Russian news reports say Russia and Turkey reached a cease-fire in Idlib, the last rebel-held province in Syria. But intense fighting continued.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Airstrikes hit the town of Khan Sheikhun in Idlib Province this month. There were reports of a cease-fire on Wednesday.

item.title: President Trump, Hong Kong, Summer Camp: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue

item.title: Trial of Catalan Independence Leaders Ends in Spain
item.description: The Spanish Supreme Court on Wednesday closed the trial of 12 leaders of the Catalan independence movement accused of staging a rebellion during their botched 2017 secession attempt.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The closing session of the Spanish Supreme Court’s trial of 12 Catalan separatist leaders was broadcast on a big screen under the Triumphal Arch in Barcelona on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Clashes erupted as Hong Kong protesters blocked roads.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner

item.title: A Canadian Store Tried to Bag-Shame Its Customers. Nice Try.
item.description: A Vancouver store introduced plastic bags with embarrassing messages to persuade customers to bring reusable alternatives. The bags became a surprise hit on social media instead.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien

item.title: The Latest Reason to Breast-feed: Milk Is Alive
item.description: Fresh breast milk may nourish a baby’s microbiome in ways that bottled breast milk can’t.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: The numbers of bacteria in breast milk are relatively low, but breast-feeding seems to have an outsize impact in populating a baby’s microbiome with good bacteria.

item.title: Scientists Find Ancient Humans Used Weed 2,500 Years Ago, Too
item.description: Residue found in tombs deep in a Central Asian mountain range suggests that strong cannabis was used in ancient burial rites.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:description: Dense patches of wild cannabis grow across the mountain foothills of Eurasia from the Caucuses to East Asia. These plants were photographed growing in the Tian Shan Mountains of Kazakhstan.

item.title: U.K. Will Cut Net Greenhouse Emissions to Zero, Theresa May Vows
item.description: The prime minister’s plan leaves many questions unanswered, but sets a new standard that she hopes other countries will adopt.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: A rally in London in May to demand action on climate change.

item.title: Hong Kong, World Cup, Alabama: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Inyoung Kang

item.title: He Couldn’t Talk About What He Saw in World War II. So He Painted It.
item.description: The aristocrat-turned-commando Guy de Montlaur was a hero of the French liberation. His paintings of D-Day depict scenes that haunted him his entire life.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: National World War II Museum (New Orleans, La)

item.title: Photos From the Hong Kong Extradition Protests
item.description: Demonstrations this week over a proposed law that would allow extraditions to mainland China have produced some of the city’s biggest shows of dissent in years.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hong Kong police used tear gas on Wednesday as protesters approached the Legislative Council, where lawmakers had been scheduled to debate a contentious extradition law.

item.title: Hong Kong, Hungary Crash, Grenfell: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A look at the rise of nationalism in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police patrol during demonstrations outside the Legislative Council building in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

item.title: Sudan’s Protesters Call Off Strike and Agree to Resume Talks With Military
item.description: Eight days after the military killed dozens of protesters in a brutal crackdown, protest leaders said they were ready to resume power-sharing talks.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh

item.title: Lebanese Man Freed by Iran Says He Shared Cell Space With American
item.description: The freed man, Nizar Zakka, who has lived in the United States for most of his life, said he and other foreign prisoners are political pawns.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Nizar Zakka during a meeting with Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon on Tuesday in Beirut.

item.title: Trump-Biden, Botswana, World Cup: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Hiroko Masuike

item.title: Survivors of London’s Grenfell Fire Sue in Philadelphia Court
item.description: Hundreds of survivors and relatives of victims in the Grenfell Tower fire sued makers of the flammable cladding and insulation that fed the blaze, one of which has its headquarters in Pennsylvania.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A year after the Grenfell fire, survivors of the disaster and relatives and friends of the victims held a vigil.

item.title: First Ebola Cases Reported in Uganda, in Spillover From Congo Outbreak
item.description: A 5-year-old Congolese boy died on Wednesday, a day after officials confirmed his case as the first outside the Democratic Republic of Congo since an outbreak began last summer.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: An Ebola treatment center in Beni, Democratic Republic of Congo. A new Ebola case in Uganda is the first outside Congo since the outbreak began last summer.

item.title: A Win for Gay Rights in Botswana Is a ‘Step Against the Current’ in Africa
item.description: Thirty-two of Africa’s 54 nations have laws that criminalize consensual same-sex conduct, according to activists. Change has come, but it is spotty and slow.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Activists leaving the Botswana High Court in Gaborone on Tuesday after the court ruled to decriminalize homosexuality. The court’s decision came about 16 years after a previous attempt to strike down Botswana’s anti-sodomy laws failed.

item.title: Hong Kong, Iowa, Danube: Hong Kong, Iowa, Danube: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Hong Kong braces for more protests.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon and Stephen Hiltner

item.title: As China Looms, Australia’s Military Refocuses on Pacific Neighbors
item.description: The Australian military’s role in regional stability is evolving in the face of a rising, powerful China and a United States in seeming retreat from the global stage.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay
item.media:description: An Australian Army exercise last month in the state of Victoria.

item.title: In Stunning Reversal, Russia Drops Charges Against Reporter
item.description: Russia’s Interior Minister announced unexpectedly that the reporter arrested on drug charges would be freed and the police investigated instead.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Ivan Golunov, a journalist who worked for the independent website Meduza, in a cage in a court room in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: China Moves to Close Gap in Trade Expertise as Clash With Trump Intensifies
item.description: Beijing called in one of its most experienced negotiators on trade policy shortly before talks with the United States collapsed, adding a veteran voice at a critical moment.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Yu Jianhua’s return from his post as China’s ambassador to the United Nations’ offices in Geneva suggests Beijing realizes an expertise gap may be hurting its ability to resolve a potentially devastating trade war with the United States.

item.title: Before Fatal Boat Crash in Budapest, Safety Warnings Went Unheeded
item.description: Traffic along the Danube, propelled by an explosion in tourism, has expanded fast, and many had pointed to the risk of overcrowding even before the accident.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Benjamin Novak

item.title: New Zealand Court, Blocking Extradition, Is Latest to Rebuke China’s Judiciary
item.description: In a strongly worded ruling, a New Zealand court ordered that human rights risks in China be considered before a murder suspect could be sent there.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Graham-McLay
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A New Zealand court said that before extraditing a murder suspect to China, the justice minister, Andrew Little, had to examine “the extent to which the judiciary is subject to political control.”

item.title: Hong Kong Residents Block Roads to Protest Extradition Bill
item.description: The police used water cannons and pepper spray against huge crowds gathered near government offices as lawmakers prepared to debate the bill.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators near the Hong Kong government’s headquarters on Wednesday morning.

item.title: Botswana’s High Court Decriminalizes Gay Sex
item.description: Activists hailed the ruling on laws that date from the British colonial era as a significant step for rights on the African continent.
item.dc:creator: Kimon de Greef
item.media:description: Outside the High Court in Gaborone, Botswana, on Tuesday after the ruling was announced.

item.title: Elizabeth Warren, Golden State Warriors, Women’s World Cup: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: When the World’s Most Famous Mystery Writer Vanished
item.description: On a cold December night in 1926, Agatha Christie went out in her beloved Morris Cowley roadster and didn’t return home for 11 days. Here’s how her disappearance played out.
item.dc:creator: Tina Jordan

item.title: Brazil Fails to Replace Cuban Doctors, Hurting Health Care of 28 Million
item.description: After Cuba recalled 8,517 doctors from Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro, the country’s new president, told Brazilians “we can solve this problem.” So far, he has failed, with millions paying the price.
item.dc:creator: Shasta Darlington and Letícia Casado
item.media:credit: Maira Erlich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients waiting to see a doctor at a clinic in Embu-Guaçu. “Now we end up doing triage all day,” said Erica Toledo, the head nurse at the Jardim Campestre clinic.

item.title: Dark Web Drug Sellers Dodge Police Crackdowns
item.description: The notorious Silk Road site was shut down in 2013. Others have followed. But the online trafficking of illegal narcotics hasn’t abated.
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel Popper
item.media:description: Supporters of Ross Ulbricht outside federal court in Manhattan during jury selection for his trial in 2015. Mr. Ulbricht, the creator of the Silk Road drug market, went to prison.

item.title: Pakistan’s Tribal Areas Are Still Waiting for Justice as Army Tightens Grip
item.description: A year after Pakistan voted to bring the Pashtun tribal areas into the national civilian court system, the army is still the master of justice there, residents say.
item.dc:creator: Ben Farmer
item.media:description: Pakistani soldiers in North Waziristan in January. The military has cracked down on protesters in the northwestern tribal belt in recent days.

item.title: Britain, the Vatican, Traveler Cyberattack: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: Colombia’s Congress Debates Censuring Defense Minister Over Army Kill Orders
item.description: Orders to “double the results” of missions against guerrilla and criminal groups sent a chill down the Colombian military’s ranks, and prompted debate in Congress over the defense minister’s future.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Iván Duque of Colombia, right, shaking hands with Maj. Gen. Nicacio Martínez Espinel, as Defense Minister Guillermo Botero, center, looks on.

item.title: Moldova Has a New Government. The Old One Is Refusing to Leave.
item.description: Two of Moldova’s largest parties formed a coalition to oust the third from power. Only one problem: Its officials have refused to vacate their offices.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The government of Moldova is at loggerheads. Supporters of the Democratic Party outside the Interior Ministry in Chisinau on Monday.

item.title: Robert Mueller, Mexico, Mindy Kaling: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Hiroko Masuike
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

item.title: Pakistan’s Former President Arrested in a Money Laundering Case
item.description: Allies of Asif Ali Zardari, the former president, say his arrest was politically motivated. His wife was Benazir Bhutto, the assassinated former prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Asif Ali Zardari, Pakistan’s former president and currently a lawmaker in Parliament, center, leaving the high court building in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Monday.

item.title: Iran Releases U.S. Resident Charged With Spying
item.description: Nizar Zakka, arrested in 2015 and convicted of spying for the United States, was released to Lebanese authorities.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Friends of Nizar Zakka group, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nizar Zakka, a Lebanese technology expert and internet freedom advocate, delivering a speech during the MENA ICT Forum conference in Jordan in 2013.

item.title: Hong Kong, Trade War, World Cup: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Hong Kong’s leader is unmoved by protests.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon and Katie Van Syckle

item.title: Leaked Messages Raise Fairness Questions in Brazil Corruption Inquiry
item.description: Private phone chats suggest that a prominent judge consulted with prosecutors in the Car Wash corruption investigation, which convicted a former president.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sérgio Moro, now Brazil’s justice minister, speaking in Manaus on Monday. He said leaked texts do not show that he acted improperly.

item.title: Huawei Tells Parliament It’s No Security Threat, Aiming to Avoid a Ban
item.description: British lawmakers questioned a Huawei executive on Monday about American allegations that the company poses a risk to national security.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Suzie Howell for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Huawei billboard in London. A Huawei executive defended the company’s security practices on Monday before a hearing in the House of Commons.

item.title: Massacre in Mali Leaves at Least 95 Dead, Government Says
item.description: An attack on a village of the Dogon ethnic group in central Mali is the latest in violence that has displaced tens of thousands of civilians.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: The Race for U.K. Prime Minister: How It’s Likely to Play Out
item.description: Can anyone beat Boris Johnson? Is the campaign making a no-deal Brexit inevitable? Find the answers to these questions and more.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain after announcing her resignation last month. Ten candidates are trying to replace her as leader of the Conservative Party.

item.title: Iran Bars Times Correspondent From Reporting
item.description: The correspondent, Thomas Erdbrink, has been unable to work since February, when his press credential was revoked. The Iranian authorities have offered no explanation.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone

item.title: Three Created a Fertility Revolution With I.V.F., but One, a Woman, Went Unrecognized
item.description: Newly released papers show that Robert Edwards, who won a Nobel Prize, tried in vain to have Jean Purdy recognized as an equal partner in the breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:credit: Central Press/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jean Purdy, a nurse and embryologist, with Robert Edwards, a physiologist, in their research laboratory in Cambridge, England, in 1968.
